saves.snippet: The Houston rapper Pimp C, who died in 2007, is now the subject of a biography — and a vivid memory for a New York Times journalist.
saves.lead_paragraph:
Sure
 2007, is now the subject of a biography — and a vivid memory for a New York Times journalist.
saves.abstract: Jon Caramanica notes that Julia Beverly's biography Sweet Jones: Pimp C's Trill Life Story offers loving look at Houston rapper Pimp C, who died tragically of drug overdose in 2007.

headline.main: Nick in a Journalist’s Back Pages

saves.snippet: As we look at search, we are always looking for ways to empower our users. One of the things that we have used internally for years is a browser search plugin, and now we would like to share that with you. There are a bunch more things related to...
saves.lead_paragraph: As we look at search, we are always looking for ways to empower our users. One of the things that we have used internally for years is a browser search plugin, and now we would like to share that with you. There are a bunch more things related to search that we would like to tell you about, but I will save those for a future post. In the meantime, please leave us a comment and let us know what you want to see.

saves.snippet: Queens Museum of Art Satellite Gallery  Bulova Corporate Center  25th Avenue, near 75th Street, Jackson Heights  Through March 16      Raymond Saá was born in Florida and raised by his mother and grandparents, Cuban exiles. He now lives and works in...
saves.lead_paragraph: Queens Museum of Art Satellite Gallery Bulova Corporate Center 25th Avenue, near 75th Street, Jackson Heights Through March 16 Raymond Saá was born in Florida and raised by his mother and grandparents, Cuban exiles. He now lives and works in Brooklyn. The biographical background is relevant, because his expansive, aggressively physical painted collages and assemblages suggest nostalgia for a mythic ancestral home while formally reflecting a late Modernist international style.
saves.abstract: Ken Johnson reviews Raymond Saa paintings at Queens Museum of Art Satellite Gallery (S)

saves.snippet: In a dispute that centers on how much of a new parallel emergency currency the government should emit, the interim president, Adolfo Rodríguez Saá, yesterday ordered David Expósito, the president of the country's most important state-run bank,...
saves.lead_paragraph: In a dispute that centers on how much of a new parallel emergency currency the government should emit, the interim president, Adolfo Rodríguez Saá, yesterday ordered David Expósito, the president of the country's most important state-run bank, Banco de la Nación, to step down. When he took office on Sunday, Mr. Rodríguez Saá announced that the new currency, the argentino, will circulate alongside the American dollar and the Argentine peso, which have the same nominal value. But he faces widespread fears that the new currency will cause inflation, concerns that grew after Mr. Expósito earlier this week proposed that the government put the equivalent of $15 billion of the new currency into circulation. Larry Rohter (NYT)
saves.abstract: Interim Pres Adolfo Rodriguez Saa orders David Exposito to step down as president of Argentina's most important state-run bank, Banco de la Nacion, in dispute that centers on how much of new parallel emergency currency should be issued by government (S)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: President Fires Banker
